data.title: Arion: A Journal of Humanities and the Classics on LinkedIn: Theodor Mommsen was born on this day in 1817. Among many other notable…
authors: Arion: A Journal of Humanities and the Classics
data.meta_description: Theodor Mommsen was born on this day in 1817. Among many other notable achievements, Mommsen would win the 1902 Nobel Prize in Literature for his mastery of…
data.text:
We had a tie in our polls this week. You can read a review of Twombly at the MFA that has a little art, poetry, translation, and book review to it here: https://buff.ly/3zKWeoX.

July 18, the dies Alliensis, was marked as a “dark day” for Rome when Brennus and the Sebrones sacked the city in the 4th century BCE. Arion invites you to look back to Geoffrey of Monmouth’s creative Historia Regum Britanniae and his version of Brenn[i]us’ career here: https://buff.ly/4czURbd

Arion highlights poet and translator Rachel Hadas, who has made more than a dozen contributions to the journal over the years. Learn more about Hadas and her work here: https://buff.ly/4cVikmQ And enjoy a small handful of her poems for Arion 24.3 here: https://buff.ly/3WiMafx

SASA’s Opening the Ancient World conference will take place online July 21-22. Learn more and register for free here: https://buff.ly/3CJGJKD.

Our summer issue will feature reviews of books on the fasces, Theocritus, and Vergilian traditions. Subscribe here to be among their first readers: www.bu.edu/arion/subscribe

This content isn’t available here

Access this content and more in the LinkedIn app

Pacuvius won by a narrow margin in our polls this week. While we don’t have his "Paullus", you can read Plutarch’s "Life of Aemilius Paullus" here: https://buff.ly/3Wgt6yx

John Quincy Adams was born on this day in 1767. Celebrate with Adams’ imitation of Horace’s integer vitae ode here: https://buff.ly/3LC7CGp. And check out Lawrence Dugan’s imitation of Adams’ imitation for Arion 31.1 here: https://buff.ly/3WdD3wF.

Arion highlights poet and translator Brian Sneeden whose translation of Phoebe Giannisi’s Chimera was published yesterday by New Directions Publishing. Learn more and order the book here: https://buff.ly/3xGlGv9 And read two of his translations of Giannisi’s poems from Arion 24.3 here: https://buff.ly/3VV29iE.

The summer issue is nearing production. Subscribe now to be among its first readers: www.bu.edu/arion/subscribe

Ancient Romans would have celebrated the Ludi Apollinares this time of year, including, perhaps, performances of fabulae praetextae.
